column1: A week had passed since they had made acquaintance. It was a holiday. It was sultry indoors
column2: while in the street the wind whirled the dust round and round
column3: and blew people's hats off. It was a thirsty day
column4: and Gurov often went into the pavilion
column5: and pressed Anna Sergeyevna to have syrup and water or an ice. One did not know what to do with oneself.In the evening when the wind had dropped a little
column6: they went out on the groyne to see the steamer come in. There were a great many people walking about the harbour; they had gathered to welcome some one
column7: bringing bouquets. And two peculiarities of a well-dressed Yalta crowd were very conspicuous: the elderly ladies were dressed like young ones
column8: and there were great numbers of generals.Owing to the roughness of the sea
column11: and it was a long time turning about before it reached the groyne. Anna Sergeyevna looked through her lorgnette at the steamer and the passengers as though looking for acquaintances
column12: and when she turned to Gurov her eyes were shining.
